A Carol for Christmas -- Phil Linehan

We three kings of Orient are
to see Baby Jesus we journeyed afar.
The going was hard for it sure isn’t comfy
to ride on a camel whose hump is quite lumpy.

The bitter winds blew us
sand storms almost slew us.
Still, we beat all the odds ‘til we came to the manger,
and shrugged off the perils that put us in danger.

We finally made it and presented our gifts
but what they should be had caused a few rifts.
Mary received them with apparent great joy
though we heard later on she’d have welcomed a toy.

We had followed the star and with consciences clear
set off for our homes and a really cold beer.
We felt very pleased that we’d met with our quest
and were sure none would grudge us our well-deserved rest.

When we turned on the tele and were quenching our thirst
the news said the Coming was only the first.
There would be a second, but no-one knew when
so it seems we are destined to set off again.

But there’s one thing we all are determined about
so we make it known now to dispel any doubt.
The next time we journey, to avoid stress and strain
our travel will be ..… business class in a plane.

Phil Linehan www.philitics.com

The key is supportive services, community building, and instilling a sense of dignity in pride in what the formerly homeless and now housed have achieved for themselves. Using section 8 vouchers we already have the housing units, we just need the supportive services to be in place. The best results seem to be in smaller projects of 12 to 20 units where everyone knows your name (sort of like at Cheers). On site supervision and oversight are the most important ingredient. Next is transitioning to permanent long-term housing with decreasing need for support but the ability to always reconnect.

It's very hard to be anti-Christmas in this country. It's ok to be a bit disillusioned when you're growing up, but depending on your family, there tends to always be a new crop of kids that come along for whom it's an important day.

My father hated Christmas, and the things he said made sense. Yet every year he would do a Scrooge, and get into the spirit. Over time I grew to despise Christmas. My family knows it, and yet for the longest time they kept hoping I would do a Scrooge.

The best Christmas I had, and coincidentally the worst Christmas my mother had was when we were in Italy in the early 90s. There wasn't the same focus on gifts and giant glittering trees. It was just a party.

I recognize that Christmas is for kids, and every year I put on a smiley face. The kids keep getting older, and there is that temptation to tell them how I feel, but I resist. No point in having them get disillusioned any earlier than they need to.

I agree that the content of a slur and the speaker's "intention" (which of course is far more complicated than what the speaker might think) have limited utility for understanding these speech acts. The arguments based on inference, similarly, do not persuade.

The problem I see with "prohibitionism," however, relates to its affective component. If I follow your argument, prohibitionism centers on the state of mind of the slur's immediate recipient who has taken "offense" at an utterance that defames himself and his self-identified group. I don't think the recipient's offense, his sense of having been defamed, or his feelings of having his self-identified group attacked by a term freighted with hatred should have anything to do with why slurs should be avoided. In other words, it may be nasty and despicable to call a person a loathsome term, but the reason we should not use slurs has nothing to do with shielding the recipient offense or to spare his feelings.

It seems to me, rather, that as a society we have chosen to attempt to discourage certain classes of deliberate slights because they are an offense to the community at large. Following from this, your "Rush Hour" example fails the test; and "in-group" slurs similarly should not be immunized and, rationally, should be proscribed as well. The community is the actor here rather than any individual or group of individuals; and both the intention of the speaker and the state of mind of the slur's recipient are both irrelevant to the analysis.

In post #151 John mentions that the Southerns who seceded, unlike the Founding fathers, thought that if they failed they would "getaway with it".

This is profoundly wrong. Read the diaries and letters of those who seceded. They were quite confident that a noose awaited them if they failed and is a main reason why the South hung on so long after victory was not possible. There is ample contemporary evidence, just like during the revolution, that the decision to revolt was done knowing the only alternative to success was death, either on the battlefield or a prison.

Further supporting this are the newspapers when Lee surrendered that by not holding out for better terms and assurances that the Confederates would not be shot he had betrayed the South and written the death warrants of the other CSA officials.

A bit off topic, but there is a speech by Lee encouraging the rest of the South to -not- take to the hills and to continue fighting a guerilla war. If I can find it I'll post a
Ink to it.

If these  revisionists were consistent, they'd whine about the Federal government "invading" them by having military bases in the South such as Ft. Bragg, Ft. Benning, Ft. Gordon, Ft. Polk, etc., etc., just like Ft. Sumter, federal property. Tariffs...straw-man,the import details are available in period documents on-line such as the Congressional Globe. The main imports to the Southern states pre-war were luxury goods such as grand pianos, fine wines, musical instruments and such. It wasn't the slaves or the non-slaveholders that were getting all fired up for war because of hated U.S. tariffs on Swiss watches and Belgian chocolates. Why the revisionists have decided that the Old Confederacy is the hill they have to defend and die on, with all the admirable history such as the South's role in the Revolution instead, is a disgrace. And further, they can stop referring to the United States Army as the "Northern Army". Many of the same US units are serving today in Afghanistan and elsewhere, they have an unbroken lineage untainted by treason, unlike many of their officers who renounced their oaths, and turned traitor to the nation that trained them and gave them their professional opportunities in the first place.

Well done, Mr. Widmer. This was a very thoughtful, well-reasoned piece. I would only add that Ward Hill Lamon's views of his good friend's religiosity ought perhaps not be summed up with, "In short, he was an infidel."

Hill said that, to be sure, but he also said, "He was not a Christian in the orthodox sense of the term, yet he was as conscientiously religious as any man."

My own favorite quote about Lincoln's faith comes from the President's own mouth:

"When any church will inscribe over its altar, as its sole qualification for membership, the Savior's condensed statement of the substance of both law and Gospel, 'Thou shalt love the lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul and thy neighbor as thyself' that church will I join with all my heart and all my soul."

And that's as succinct a summary of the Judeo-Christian tradition as we'll anywhere. Happy Holidays!

"the judgments of the Lord are good and righteous altogether."

For those with faith, or who seek it, this statement enables us to make some sense of what often seems like celestial nonesense and global chaos.

Some suggest that support of rights of states against federal encroachment is immoral. I think it is erroneous to take one use of states rights (defense of slavery) and argue that all uses of states rights are immoral. Consider other contexts. Were the member states of the Austro-Hungarian Empire wrong to secede? How about the member states of Yuglosavia? Also, today in the Euro zone the Euro states resist surrendering more sovereignty to Brussels. What is immoral about this opposition? Nothing I can see. It is just a difference in opinion about how a group should be ruled.

It is natural for people in locales and other smaller areas to oppose being dictated to by people in other areas who just happen to be more numerous or powerful. I fail to see what is morally illegitimate about all cases of opposition to rules made up by other populations, whether in a democratic republic or in some other form of government.

It is a mistake to see all issues thru the prism of a single conflict, whether that conflict be the US Civil War or WWII or some other war. It is all too easy to use events from a past conflict to take cheap shots at some other faction you disagree with today. Those cheap shots just harden your opponents against you and do nothing to improve the quality of debate and governance.
My reading of the Lincoln's first inaugural is that he would "have no objection" to the adoption of the amendment as it reflected settled law.  That's different from saying he supported it.
